meanings.definition: To approach, stop, and speak to somebody in an aggressive or insistent way.
meanings.examples: The thief accosted the man and took all his money.

meanings.definition: To move forward toward a place or a goal.
examples: After we advanced on the road all day long, we finally reached the end of our trip.

meanings.definition: To upset or disturb.
examples: I think loud, unexpected noises are alarming.

meanings.definition: Even though, while.
examples: I had to take the math test, although I had not studied for it.

meanings.definition: To gather together in one place.
examples: All grades assembled in the auditorium for a school meeting.

meanings.definition: Finally and as a result of a series of events.
examples: The baby, at length, fell asleep after crying for over an hour.

meanings.definition: An action that is shocking in its degree of cruelty.
examples: Killing someone is an atrocity.

meanings.definition: Something that is true, not fake or misleading.
examples: The gold bracelet was authentic, not fake costume jewelry.

meanings.definition: To block or close off.
examples: The shoppers tried to get into the store, but large crowds barred the doorway.

meanings.definition: An organized group of people.
examples: A large body of people gathered to see the movie star.

meanings.definition: An organized group of soldiers.
examples: There were about 50 soldiers in the body of troops I saw march in the parade.

meanings.definition: People who are part of the same group, such as family or community.
examples: Sometimes I call my close friends my brethren, because we have a great deal in common.

meanings.definition: To gather.
examples: I collected all of my baseball cards together in one pile.

meanings.definition: A representative is someone who speaks or votes for a group of people. A colonial representative speaks or votes for people who live in colonies, places that are ruled by another, more powerful country.
examples: The colonial representatives from New England spoke out against any new taxes that the English wanted to raise from the American colonies.

meanings.definition: An area that is ruled by another country. The American colonies were ruled by Great Britain.
examples: Louisiana was a French colony before it became part of the United States.

meanings.definition: To start or begin to happen.
examples: The school day commenced as soon as the opening bell rang.

meanings.definition: A grassy area of land that is set aside for public use. Commons, or greens, in colonial times were used as a space to meet and where all townspeople could graze their cattle.
examples: Today, the town common in Boston is a large, grassy park in front of the State Capitol building.

meanings.definition: An organized group.
examples: The company of soldiers was sent off to war last month.

meanings.definition: To decide after considering all the facts.
examples: I wrote an essay about television and concluded that, while it is fun to watch, I learn more by reading.

meanings.definition: Without any kind of plan or organization.
examples: People were left in confusion after the hurricane passed through New Orleans.

meanings.definition: ‘This colony’ was Massachusetts. The Congress is the part of government that makes laws and that most directly represents the people.
examples: In Connecticut, the Congress of this colony would mean the part of Connecticut government that passes laws.

meanings.definition: A large amount.
examples: The line was long and we waited a considerable amount of time before we got to go into the movie theatre.

meanings.definition: To ask the opinion of others before taking action.
examples: I was not sure how to study for the test, so I decided to consult with my friends on how they planned to study.

meanings.definition: The group of delegates from each of the American colonies who met before, during, and after the American Revolution.
examples: The Continental Congress passed laws for the American colonies during the American Revolution.

meanings.definition: Opposite or against.
examples: The car went the wrong way up the one-way street, contrary to what the signs directed the traffic to do.

meanings.definition: Testimony that is given by a witness under oath which can later be read in court when the witness is absent.
examples: My uncle was in the hospital, so he had to give his testimony through a deposition instead of coming to the courthouse himself.

meanings.definition: To separate from something else.
examples: I detached all the tags from any new toys before I gave them to my baby brother.

meanings.definition: A small military unit separated from its normal, larger unit for a special mission.
examples: Just five soldiers, out of a group of fifty, were chosen to be a special detachment to cross enemy lines.

meanings.definition: To force another army to give up their weapons.
examples: Police make sure to disarm anyone they arrest so that no one can get hurt.

meanings.definition: To shoot or fire off.
examples: The gun accidentally discharged and hurt someone.

meanings.definition: Found unexpectedly.
examples: I heard a loud noise and when I looked out the window, I discovered that a raccoon was tipping over our trash can.

meanings.definition: To send someone away to accomplish a task.
examples: We were unsure of where we were, so I dispatched three groups to find what direction we needed to go.

meanings.definition: To move or scatter away in different directions.
examples: I burnt the popcorn, so I opened the window to disperse the smoke.

meanings.definition: The amount of space that separates two things or places.
examples: My house is a long distance from school, so I take the bus in the mornings.

meanings.definition: General idea, main point or essential meaning.
examples: She said that she wanted to go with me to the get lunch, or words to that effect.

meanings.definition: Under attack.
examples: I feel embattled when I have too many papers due all at once.

meanings.definition: Move in a line, one behind the other.
examples: The students walked, single file, through the hall to their next class.

meanings.definition: The right or left side of a line of soldiers, usually when they are in battle.
examples: I stood in the center, and on my sides were the right and left flanks of the army.

meanings.definition: A shallow part of a river or stream where people can cross to the other side.
examples: The river was wide and deep everywhere but at the ford, where it was easy to cross through the shallow water.

meanings.definition: Money and property.
examples: The gambler lost his entire fortune when he lost the card game.

meanings.definition: In a very fast and violent way.
examples: My sister yelled furiously at me when I broke her favorite necklace.

meanings.definition: A person, either appointed or elected, who is the leader of a state or colony.
A grassy area of land that is set aside for public use. Greens, or commons, in colonial times were used as a space to meet and where all townspeople could graze their cattle.
examples: Places that used to be as town greens are now used as public parks.

meanings.definition: A small number.
examples: My friend got many books at the library, but I only took out a handful.

headword: his person, family, crown, and dignity.

meanings.definition: An expression that means everything that is valuable to a person.
Fighting against someone.
examples: Hostilities ended when each side agreed to stop fighting.

meanings.definition: Shouted, usually used to mean happiness or encouragement.
examples: A loud huzzah came from the miners when they saw that they had found gold.

meanings.definition: A person who lives in a particular place.
examples: The inhabitants of my home are all members of my family.

meanings.definition: Very cruel and vicious.
examples: Mistreating a family pet seems like an inhuman thing to do.

meanings.definition: To ask a question about something.
examples: I was unsure of how to get to my friend’s house, so I stopped in a shop to inquire if her street was nearby.

meanings.definition: Happening in the current month or year in which the author is writing.
examples: I just had my birthday party, on the fifteenth of December instant.

meanings.definition: Something that happens right after something else.
examples: When our teacher announced that the test was cancelled, we instantaneously began to cheer.

meanings.definition: Right away and without any waiting.
examples: I touched the hot stove and instantly pulled my hand away.

meanings.definition: Information about secret plans or activities.
examples: We make sure that our intelligence is correct before we make any decisions.

meanings.definition: To have a plan to do something.
examples: Jose was so angry, he left the restaurant intending to never return.

meanings.definition: Infantry is the soldiers who are trained to fight on foot rather than from vehicles. Light infantry soldiers are foot soldiers specially trained to fight independently rather than just as one large group. Each soldier is trained to be able to fight in a small, one-on-one skirmish with the enemy.
examples: The light infantry ran onto the battlefield as the cannon fired at the enemy soldiers.

meanings.definition: Interfere in an unwanted way.
examples: Do not meddle into the business of other people unless they ask you!

meanings.definition: A large building where people gathered in colonial times. A meetinghouse was the town church on Sundays. On other days, the meetinghouse was a place where people could meet.
examples: An old meetinghouse is built in the center of the of my town.

meanings.definition: Things related to the army, navy, or other branch of the armed forces.
examples: People in the military wear uniforms when they are on duty.

meanings.definition: A group of people which is not part of the regular army but which can be called together to fight in an emergency.
examples: The militia practiced every day so that it would be ready if the regular army needed help.

meanings.definition: Connected to a government minister or department.
examples: The heads of government in England give the English king or queen ministerial advice.

meanings.definition: A government department headed by a minister. A minister is a senior official in a government department.
examples: The Ministry of Defense is one of the departments of the British government.

meanings.definition: To gather together for inspection or to prepare for military action.
examples: The group of volunteer fire fighters mustered at the firehouse to practice working with the new equipment.

meanings.definition: To be nearby or close to another.
examples: Connecticut and Rhode Island are neighboring states because they are next to each other.

meanings.definition: A time when something happens.
examples: I love parties and other happy occasions.

meanings.definition: To resist or be against something.
examples: The other football team was ready to oppose us and tried to block the goal.

meanings.definition: Individual fact, item, or detail.
examples: The newspaper told all the particulars of the bank robbery.

meanings.definition: The individual or group of people who are gathered to act together.
examples: On Halloween, you see many small parties of children dressed in costume.

meanings.definition: To happen, to take place.
examples: I called my sister to tell her what events passed last weekend.

meanings.definition: A person who supports or defends their country.
examples: The people we now think of as patriots, Americans that fought against the British during the Revolutionary War, were thought of as traitors in England.

meanings.definition: Cruel or unfair treatment.
examples: A person who is jailed but has not committed a crime is being subjected to persecution.

meanings.definition: A small gun that is made to be held in one hand.
examples: The pistol I saw at a museum had a curved wooden handle and a narrow metal barrel.

meanings.definition: Clear and with no doubt.
examples: I am positive that I know how to get to the mall.

meanings.definition: To own or hold something.
examples: I have some of my friend’s CDs in my possession, because she let me borrow them.

meanings.definition: An event.
examples: The court reporter wrote down all the proceedings that happened during the trial.

meanings.definition: To make a public statement which openly admits something.
examples: She professed her belief that all people are created equal to the large audience.

meanings.definition: An area controlled by another country.
examples: Quebec is a province of Canada.

meanings.definition: Related to an area or person controlled by another country. The Massachusetts Provincial Congress was the part of Massachusetts government that could make laws for the Massachusetts area.
examples: The day to day laws of the colonies were passed by the provincial congress.

meanings.definition: Actions, words, or something else that makes someone angry.
examples: Most dogs are nice, but some will bark and bite others with very little provocation.

meanings.definition: made them run away.
examples: A dog ran toward the cats and put them to flight.

meanings.definition: Someone who fights against a government.
examples: In the Civil War, people in the North called people from the South ‘rebels’ because they were fighting against the Federal Government in Washington, D.C..

meanings.definition: Full-time professional soldiers.
examples: The regular troops were well trained and were good at fighting on big battlefields.

meanings.definition: An act that follows normal rules.
examples: The rain fell in uneven bursts, without any pattern or regularity.

meanings.definition: Saying or doing something again.
examples: The more repetitions I do on the fitness machines, the stronger I will become.

meanings.definition: Referring to something that was already named or mentioned.
examples: I wrote a letter and then went to mail said letter at the post office.

meanings.definition: Hold, protect or make safe.
examples: The store was locked and secured for the night.

meanings.definition: The time over which a meeting of a court or branch of government meets.
examples: The singers practiced for three sessions before performing the music at the concert.

meanings.definition: Shots. The Americans fired their guns at the British soldiers.
examples: He crouched down low when he heard several shott fired close by.

meanings.definition: The other 12 American colonies.
examples: Virginia and Massachusetts were sister colonies before they became part of the new United States.

meanings.definition: The ruler of a country, especially a king or queen.
examples: Queen Elizabeth II is the royal Sovereign of England.

meanings.definition: They stayed right where they were and did not move.
examples: The guards stood their ground in front of the building, even though the crowd tired to push them out of the way.

meanings.definition: A willingness to surrender.
examples: When the police caught the bank robber, he held his hands up in a sign of submission.

meanings.definition: Give into somebody else’s control or demands.
examples: I will not submit to any law that I think is unfair.

meanings.definition: Move so that all the space around something is taken and there is no way to escape.
examples: Adult elephants gather together and surround their babies to protect them from predators.

meanings.definition: Riding a horse very fast.
examples: The horse and swift-riding jockey won the horse race.

meanings.definition: To promise that what you say or write is the truth.
examples: The witness was sworn in first and then told what she saw happen.

meanings.definition: Gently, or without any kind of fight or resistance.
examples: The gentle breeze blew tamely through the trees.

meanings.definition: The name of an army group, in this case this refers to one of the British army groups.
examples: All the soldiers in the Tenth army regiment arrived safely home at the end of the war.

meanings.definition: They hid behind low stone walls that were in the fields.
Given secret information ahead of time.
examples: My friend tipped me off that I can win the video game by getting a special key to open a room.

meanings.definition: To get hold of, capture.
examples: I took three chess pieces from my opponent before he got even one of mine.

meanings.definition: An event. In this case, the event is the battle of Lexington.
examples: I went to the bank and did several transactions, including cashing my check and depositing some money.

meanings.definition: To pass along a message or some information.
examples: Colds spread when germs are transmitted from one person to another.

meanings.definition: A unit of soldiers.
examples: The troops marched down the street in a tight group during the parade.

meanings.definition: The harsh use of power over others.
examples: When all power is in the hands of one person and no one has any right to complain, that is tyranny.

meanings.definition: Describing a state where people are ready to use weapons.
examples: Because everyone was told to be under arms, I knew that they would all be carrying a gun or some other weapon.

meanings.definition: Up to our waists.
examples: The water in shallow end of the pool came up to our middles, just about to our waists.

meanings.definition: A harsh punishment that is in response to another act.
examples: After the driver hit our family pet, I wanted vengeance.

meanings.definition: When many weapons, especially guns, are fired at the same time.
examples: When they heard the order to fire, the soldiers fired a volley of shots at the enemy.

meanings.definition: A cut or other injury that causes bleeding.
examples: I wounded my elbow when I fell down on the sidewalk.
